name: Adobe
title: Identity: the new battleground in our emerging AI world | SC Media
description:
COMMENTARY: Security leaders and practitioners face new and increasingly complex identity‑based threats including phishing, credential theft, deepfakes, and privilege misuse.
Organizations adopt AI‑driven identity validation and behavioral analytics to validate identities, detect anomalies and terminate high-risk behavior in real time.
Organizations that embed AI into identity and access frameworks can potentially gain visibility and resilience.
At Black Hat USA alone, 40% said their organization does not consistently enforce MFA for privileged accounts.
Modernizing identity controls and integrating AI thoughtfully into their security stack can help organizations withstand today’s threats and build secure, scalable growth for the future.
text:
COMMENTARY: Security leaders and practitioners face new and increasingly complex identity‑based threats including phishing, credential theft, deepfakes, and privilege misuse.

Nearly 80% of detections in CrowdStrike’s 2025 Global Threat Report were malware‑free, indicating that attackers relied on other techniques, such as social engineering and stolen credentials, to impersonate legitimate users, bypass controls, and escalate privileges.

[SC Media Perspectives columns are written by a trusted community of SC Media cybersecurity subject matter experts.Read more Perspectives here.]

To better understand the challenges organizations face today, we gathered insights from attendees at three major global cybersecurity conferences in 2025: Black Hat USA in Las Vegas; Infosecurity Europe in London; and the it-sa Expo&Congress in Nuremberg. Across all regions, practitioners cited identity as the new perimeter.

Why all the focus on identity?

Survey respondents consistently reported that identity‑based threats now surpass all other cyber risks. Phishing, credential theft, deepfakes, and privilege misuse ranked ahead of ransomware as the most likely sources of major breaches over the coming year. At Black Hat USA, 45% identified phishing as their primary concern and 41% cited deepfakes. Infosecurity Europe mirrored those results with phishing as the top identity-based threat for 50% of respondents and deepfakes for 42%.

These statistics reflect real‑world, costly incidents. The September 2025 Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) cyberattack demonstrates how identity‑based techniques, including vishing and credential theft, can cripple an organization’s global operations. Threat actors from Scattered Spider, Lapsus$ and ShinyHunters infiltrated JLR’s IT environment, causing severe production shutdowns and supply chain disruptions.

Digital identities have proliferated as hybrid, multi‑cloud and AI‑enabled environments expand. Every user, device and non‑human identity (NHI) represents a potential entry point. Outdated authentication methods and incomplete identity governance heighten exposure, making modernization an urgent priority.

AI: a double-edged sword

Cybercriminals now use AI to create more convincing phishing campaigns, generate deepfakes, automate ransomware and escalate privileges at scale.

However, confidence in defending against AI‑enhanced attacks remains low across regions. Only 12% of Infosecurity Europe respondents and 16% at Black Hat USA said their organizations are fully prepared. At it-sa Expo&Congress, readiness was slightly higher at 28%, but nearly one‑third of respondents expressed only partial confidence.

AI‑enhanced attacks are mainstream threats. Financial institutions report AI-driven voice cloning that circumvents authentication, and enterprises face increasingly targeted spear phishing attacks. Low‑level criminals can now impersonate executives with off-the-shelf deepfake tools.

While AI creates new risks, it also unlocks defensive advantages. Organizations adopt AI‑driven identity validation and behavioral analytics to validate identities, detect anomalies and terminate high-risk behavior in real time.

More than half of respondents across all three regions cited AI‑driven validation as the most impactful innovation for identity security, with 53% at Infosecurity Europe, 57% at Black Hat USA and 60% at it-sa Expo&Congress. Organizations that embed AI into identity and access frameworks can potentially gain visibility and resilience. Those that hesitate to adopt AI-enabled technologies risk falling behind amid accelerating threats and rising automation.

The importance of privileged access management

Despite universal agreement that identity has become central to cybersecurity, privileged access controls remain inconsistent. Security leaders know the path forward: strengthen privileged access, enforce multi-factor authentication (MFA) and operationalize zero-trust.

Yet gaps persist. Across all three conferences, four in 10 organizations lack consistent MFA enforcement or comprehensive privileged access management (PAM) coverage. At Black Hat USA alone, 40% said their organization does not consistently enforce MFA for privileged accounts.

The February 2024 Change Healthcare attack, which compromised the data of more than 190 million Americans, stemmed from a single server lacking basic MFA. Bridging the divide between awareness and execution demands disciplined processes, continuous measurement and responsible use of AI across every layer of defense.

Achieving cyber resilience requires converting awareness into action. Here's what to do: secure identities, enforce least privilege, and embrace intelligent automation.

Modernizing identity controls and integrating AI thoughtfully into their security stack can help organizations withstand today’s threats and build secure, scalable growth for the future.

Darren Guccione, co-founder and CEO, Keeper Security

SC Media Perspectives columns are written by a trusted community of SC Media cybersecurity subject matter experts. Each contribution has a goal of bringing a unique voice to important cybersecurity topics. Content strives to be of the highest quality, objective and non-commercial.

name: Medtronic
title: Medtronic's MiniMed files for US IPO | 1470 & 100.3 WMBD
description:
Dec 19 (Reuters) – MiniMed Group, the diabetes business of medical ‍device maker Medtronic, filed for an initial public offering in the United States on Friday.
Fuel distributor ‍ARKO Petroleum and drug developer Aktis Oncology also publicly filed paperwork for a New ‍York IPO on Friday.
MiniMed will list on the Nasdaq ‍under ‍the symbol “MMED”.
Goldman ​Sachs, BofA Securities, ​Citigroup ⁠and Morgan Stanley ‌are the lead underwriters for the IPO.
(Reporting by Arasu Kannagi Basil in Bengaluru; Editing by Shinjini ⁠Ganguli)
text:
Dec 19 (Reuters) – MiniMed Group, the diabetes business of medical ‍device maker Medtronic, filed for an initial public offering in the United States on Friday.

With ‌capital markets set ‌for the year-end holidays slowdown, corporate issuers are laying the groundwork for a ​potential roadshow launch in early 2026 ‍when the ​IPO market kicks ​back into action.

Fuel distributor ‍ARKO Petroleum and drug developer Aktis Oncology also publicly filed paperwork for a New ‍York IPO on Friday.

MiniMed will list on the Nasdaq ‍under ‍the symbol “MMED”. Goldman ​Sachs, BofA Securities, ​Citigroup ⁠and Morgan Stanley ‌are the lead underwriters for the IPO.

(Reporting by Arasu Kannagi Basil in Bengaluru; Editing by Shinjini ⁠Ganguli)

name: Contentsquare
title: Contentsquare brings AI analytics to Shopify checkout process - PPC Land
description:
Contentsquare announced a partnership with Shopify on December 17, 2025, providing analytics capabilities across the complete ecommerce journey from initial site entry through checkout completion.
Measurement capabilities across checkout infrastructure The Contentsquare platform captures granular behavioral data throughout Shopify checkout flows.
Analytics capabilities within Product Network remain limited in initial documentation, though demonstration materials showed performance tracking across placements and category analysis.
Each platform emphasizes different measurement methodologies—product analytics, marketing analytics, behavioral analytics—creating segmented market positioning.
The integration specifically extends Contentsquare's behavioral analytics capabilities into Shopify checkout flows without requiring engineering work or custom pixel implementations.
text:
Contentsquare announced a partnership with Shopify on December 17, 2025, providing analytics capabilities across the complete ecommerce journey from initial site entry through checkout completion. The collaboration extends behavioral measurement tools to Shopify's commerce platform, which powers millions of businesses across more than 175 countries.

The partnership addresses friction identification in digital shopping experiences. More than 1.3 million websites worldwide currently use Contentsquare's analytics platform, and the Shopify integration gives merchants access to session replay, heatmaps, zone-based analysis, performance monitoring, and AI-powered insights specifically within checkout flows.

"Shopify gives brands the foundation to grow, and Contentsquare shows them how to make every customer interaction count," said Jean-Christophe Pitié, Chief Marketing and Partner Officer at Contentsquare. "With this partnership, teams finally get full visibility into the moments that drive revenue — and the ones that create friction — so they can fix issues faster and deliver the kind of shopping experience customers actually come back for."

The technical implementation centers on a new Contentsquare Shopify Partner app that enables data collection without requiring engineering work, custom pixel implementations, or manual tagging plans. Installation occurs through a streamlined process designed for rapid deployment.

Measurement capabilities across checkout infrastructure

The Contentsquare platform captures granular behavioral data throughout Shopify checkout flows. Session replay functionality records individual customer sessions, showing exact navigation paths, click patterns, and points where shoppers abandon transactions. This visual playback capability operates independently of aggregate analytics, providing teams with detailed views of specific user experiences.

Heatmaps display which page elements attract engagement and which areas customers ignore. The zone-based approach breaks pages into discrete components, measuring performance at element-level granularity. Teams can analyze how placement, merchandising strategies, and cross-sell implementations affect engagement and sales outcomes.

Frustration scoring represents a core measurement methodology within the platform. The system detects signals indicating customer struggle, including rage clicks, repeated form field attempts, and error encounters. AI-powered analytics platforms score these frustration indicators, ranking sessions by business impact to prioritize technical resolutions.

Performance monitoring surfaces technical issues affecting revenue. The platform tracks page load speeds, broken elements, and errors that create friction during checkout processes. These signals combine with behavioral data to quantify how technical problems impact conversion rates.

Shopify Plus enterprise brands gain access to journey visualization showing how shoppers browse, search, and navigate across product categories. The complete view spans from first interaction through post-purchase, connecting disparate touchpoints into unified customer paths.

Integration mechanics and data architecture

The Shopify Partner app installation process eliminates traditional implementation barriers that require developer resources. Automatic data capture begins immediately after activation, tracking all interactions within the checkout environment without manual configuration requirements.

Zoning functionality automatically segments each page into measurable components. Teams can examine individual element performance without creating custom tracking specifications. This automated approach reduces the setup time typically associated with granular analytics implementations.

The platform processes event-scoped data, session-scoped measurements, and user-level aggregations. Event data captures specific interactions like button clicks or form submissions. Session data encompasses complete visit sequences. User data tracks behavior across multiple sessions, enabling lifecycle analysis and repeat purchase pattern identification.

Data flows into Contentsquare's analysis infrastructure where AI models process behavioral signals. The system identifies highest-impact optimization opportunities, flagging specific pages, elements, or flows where improvements would generate measurable conversion increases. Teams receive prioritized recommendations rather than undifferentiated data sets requiring manual interpretation.

Voice of customer capabilities integrate survey responses with behavioral data. When customers provide feedback, teams can access session replays showing the exact experience that prompted the response. This connection between qualitative feedback and quantitative behavior enables more precise diagnostic work.

Market context for ecommerce analytics

The Shopify partnership arrives as analytics platforms expand capabilities for measuring digital commerce. Google Analytics expanded ecommerce dimensions and metrics availability in reporting tools on August 25, 2025, addressing limitations in how merchants access product performance data. That enhancement enabled secondary dimensions, filters, comparisons, and customization options for ecommerce measurements that previously remained restricted.

Shopify's platform evolution has emphasized merchant tools and infrastructure components. The company launched Commerce Components on January 6, 2023, providing enterprise retailers with modular access to checkout systems and flexible APIs for custom integrations. That approach allowed retailers to adopt specific Shopify capabilities without migrating entire technology stacks.

More recently, Shopify announced the Product Network on December 10, 2025. The system enables product displays from third-party merchants across multiple storefronts, creating unified checkout experiences. Analytics capabilities within Product Network remain limited in initial documentation, though demonstration materials showed performance tracking across placements and category analysis.

Platform consolidation trends affect commerce infrastructure decisions. Meta phased out Facebook and Instagram shops checkout by August 2025, redirecting transactions to merchant websites. That shift eliminated payment processing responsibilities while maintaining advertising value propositions. For Shopify merchants specifically, Meta indicated order attribution would be temporarily lost during transition periods.

Analytics platform selection increasingly depends on integration depth and measurement granularity. Google Analytics published a reporting playbook in October 2025 addressing platform complexity across five reporting surfaces: Reports, Explore, Advertising, Data API, and BigQuery export. The documentation explained data scope hierarchies spanning user-level, session-level, event-level, and item-level measurements.

Technical specifications and use cases

Session replay within Contentsquare operates through smart capture technology that records all journey data while automatically masking personal information including payment details. Teams can review individual sessions or examine aggregated patterns across customer segments.

Event stream functionality highlights specific moments within replays. The system automatically identifies events affecting business outcomes—form submissions, site errors, checkout abandonment points—and creates timeline markers enabling teams to skip directly to relevant moments rather than reviewing complete sessions.

The platform provides session replay summaries using AI to distill single or multiple user sessions into concise overviews. This condensed format accelerates analysis by presenting key insights without requiring teams to review hours of footage.

Event-triggered recording captures sessions related to specific behaviors. Teams can configure the system to record only sessions containing negative feedback, cart abandonment, or error encounters. This selective approach reduces data volume while ensuring capture of high-priority interactions.

A/B testing analysis connects directly to session replay and heatmap data. When teams run experiments, they can examine why specific variants outperform others by reviewing actual customer behavior within each version. This behavioral context supplements statistical significance measurements with actionable insights about what elements drive performance differences.

Form analysis specifically addresses checkout friction. The platform measures completion rates, identifies frequently abandoned fields, and surfaces confusion indicators. Teams can examine heatmaps showing where customers hesitate or struggle, then access replays demonstrating actual form navigation patterns.

Impact quantification ranks sessions by business consequences. Rather than presenting all sessions equally, the system prioritizes replays where customers experienced significant friction, completed high-value purchases, or represented important segments. This filtering enables teams to focus analytical efforts on interactions with meaningful revenue implications.

Zone-based heatmaps extend beyond click tracking to attribution modeling. The platform calculates exposure rates, click rates, conversion rates, and revenue attribution for each page element. These measurements enable comparisons showing which images, calls-to-action, or product placements generate optimal outcomes.

Side-by-side heatmap analysis supports temporal comparisons, traffic source evaluations, and device-type assessments. Teams can examine how page element performance varies across different time periods, referral sources, or mobile versus desktop contexts.

Broader industry implications

The partnership reflects convergent trends around friction detection, AI-powered analysis, and checkout optimization. Customer experience platforms face mounting pressure to demonstrate clear return on investment. Sprinklr reported implementation difficulties with larger Contact Center as a Service projects on June 4, 2025, resulting in customer dissatisfaction and revenue recognition delays.

Analytical capabilities increasingly differentiate commerce platforms. Data governance challenges create barriers to AI implementation across industries. Research from Publicis Sapient showed 63 percent of energy sector leaders identified poor data quality as a top barrier to drawing insights, while 61 percent of telecommunications executives cited technical data debt delaying customer experience innovation.

The Contentsquare-Shopify integration addresses these concerns through automatic data capture eliminating manual configuration requirements. Clean, structured behavioral data flows into analysis systems without depending on merchant data governance practices.

Platform ecosystems continue expanding analytical tool access. Google Analytics added nine new data sources for cost data import on June 24, 2025, including BigQuery, Amazon Redshift, Amazon S3, and Snowflake. That expansion enabled marketers to consolidate advertising spend data from multiple platforms into unified interfaces.

Similar integration strategies appear across the martech landscape. Optimizely acquired NetSpring on September 30, 2024, bringing warehouse-native analytics capabilities to its experimentation platform. The acquisition enabled customers to connect experimentation activities directly to business metrics stored in data warehouses, processing analysis within existing data infrastructure.

Measurement methodologies emphasize connecting digital interactions to revenue outcomes. Traditional analytics platforms track page views, session durations, and bounce rates as proxy metrics. Behavioral analytics platforms like Contentsquare attempt more direct connections between specific customer actions and conversion events.

This shift from descriptive to diagnostic analytics changes how teams approach optimization. Instead of observing that conversion rates declined, teams can identify which page elements, technical errors, or checkout steps caused the decline. This diagnostic precision accelerates resolution cycles and focuses development resources on highest-impact fixes.

Privacy considerations and data handling

The Contentsquare platform implements automatic personal information masking. Payment card details, banking information, and other sensitive data undergo redaction during session recording. Teams can review customer behavior without accessing personally identifiable information.

Data processing occurs within Contentsquare's infrastructure rather than exposing raw behavioral data to merchant systems. This architecture reduces merchant responsibilities for behavioral data governance while maintaining measurement capabilities.

The platform operates within Shopify's ecosystem, avoiding third-party data sharing concerns that complicate retail media partnerships with external advertising platforms. All transactions and measurements occur within Shopify-managed systems with existing merchant relationships and user consent frameworks.

Cookie consent and tracking permission management remain merchant responsibilities. Contentsquare respects browser-level privacy controls and consent management platform configurations. When users decline tracking, behavioral monitoring ceases.

Implementation timeline and availability

The Contentsquare Shopify Partner app became available on December 17, 2025. Installation requires Shopify Plus for enterprise brands seeking complete feature access across checkout flows. Standard Shopify plans receive experience analytics features across storefronts excluding specific checkout measurement capabilities.

The partnership includes experience monitoring, user lifecycle analysis, and voice of customer features extending beyond checkout. These capabilities apply across the entire merchant storefront, providing comprehensive visibility into customer behavior from site entry through post-purchase.

Merchants using the platform can configure alerting for sudden frustration increases or technical error spikes. These proactive notifications enable rapid response to emerging issues before they significantly impact conversion rates.

The collaboration positions Contentsquare within Shopify's partner ecosystem alongside other analytics, marketing automation, and customer experience vendors. Merchants can combine Contentsquare behavioral insights with complementary tools addressing email marketing, advertising attribution, inventory management, and customer relationship management.

Technical requirements specify JavaScript compatibility and browser cookie support. Mobile app analytics extend to Shopify mobile commerce implementations, capturing touch interactions, swipe patterns, and mobile-specific navigation behaviors.

Data retention policies determine how long session recordings and behavioral measurements remain accessible. Merchants can configure retention periods balancing analytical needs against storage costs and privacy considerations.

Strategic positioning within commerce infrastructure

The announcement reflects Shopify's strategy of expanding merchant capabilities through partner integrations rather than building all functionality internally. This approach enables rapid feature deployment while allowing Shopify to focus engineering resources on core commerce platform development.

For Contentsquare, the partnership provides distribution to Shopify's merchant base. The company already serves more than 1.3 million websites globally, and Shopify represents substantial expansion opportunity within the ecommerce vertical.

Competing analytics platforms include Adobe Analytics, Google Analytics 4, Amplitude, Mixpanel, and Heap. Each platform emphasizes different measurement methodologies—product analytics, marketing analytics, behavioral analytics—creating segmented market positioning.

Session replay capabilities specifically have become standard features across customer experience platforms. However, implementation quality, AI-powered analysis, and integration depth vary significantly. Contentsquare differentiates through automated friction detection and impact quantification rather than providing undifferentiated session recording.

The focus on checkout flows addresses critical conversion points where small improvements generate outsized revenue impacts. Cart abandonment rates typically range from 60 to 80 percent across ecommerce sites, representing substantial recovery opportunities for merchants identifying and resolving specific friction sources.

The partnership arrives during peak shopping season preparation periods when merchants configure analytics and optimization tools for holiday traffic. Timing the announcement for December 17 positions the platform for implementation ahead of 2026 planning cycles.

Timeline

December 17, 2025: Contentsquare announces partnership with Shopify, launching Partner app providing session replay, heatmaps, and AI analytics across checkout flows

December 10, 2025: Shopify launches Product Network enabling cross-merchant product displays with preliminary analytics capabilities

November 19, 2025: Google Analytics renames cost data import feature to campaign data import, maintaining functionality while clarifying scope

October 2025: Google Analytics publishes comprehensive reporting playbook addressing platform complexity across reporting surfaces

August 25, 2025: Google Analytics expands ecommerce dimensions and metrics in reporting tools, removing previous access restrictions

June 28, 2025: Google Analytics adds nine new data sources for cost data import including BigQuery and Amazon platforms

June 4, 2025: Sprinklr reports implementation challenges with customer experience projects causing dissatisfaction and retention issues

January 6, 2023: Shopify launches Commerce Components providing enterprise retailers with modular infrastructure access

Summary

Who: Contentsquare, an AI-powered digital analytics platform serving more than 1.3 million websites globally, partnered with Shopify, the commerce platform powering millions of businesses across more than 175 countries. Jean-Christophe Pitié serves as Chief Marketing and Partner Officer at Contentsquare.

What: The partnership delivers complete customer experience visibility across ecommerce journeys through a Shopify Partner app enabling session replay, heatmaps, zoning analysis, performance monitoring, frustration scoring, and AI-powered insights. The integration specifically extends Contentsquare's behavioral analytics capabilities into Shopify checkout flows without requiring engineering work or custom pixel implementations. Shopify Plus enterprise brands gain access to journey visualization, root cause detection using AI, product performance analysis, A/B testing enhancement, and loyalty optimization features.

When: Contentsquare announced the partnership on December 17, 2025, with the Shopify Partner app immediately available for installation. The timing positions the platform for implementation during peak shopping season preparation and ahead of 2026 planning cycles.

Where: The partnership operates within Shopify's global commerce ecosystem spanning more than 175 countries. Implementation occurs through the Shopify Partner app marketplace, with data processing in Contentsquare's analytics infrastructure. Measurement capabilities extend across web storefronts and mobile commerce implementations. Brands using the platform include enterprise retailers already on Shopify such as Glossier, Coty, Steve Madden, Spanx, and Staples.

description:
Medtronic (MDT) announced that its diabetes business, which as previously announced will operate under the name MiniMed (MMED), has filed a registration statement on Form S-1 with the SEC for a proposed initial public offering of newly issued common stock.
The separation is expected to be completed through a series of capital markets transactions, with a preferred path of an IPO and subsequent split-off.
MiniMed intends to apply to have its common stock listed on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol MMED.
The IPO is expected to commence after the completion of the SEC review process, subject to market and other conditions.
Goldman Sachs & Co., BofA Securities, Citigroup and Morgan Stanley will act as the active bookrunners for the proposed offering.
text:
Medtronic (MDT) announced that its diabetes business, which as previously announced will operate under the name MiniMed (MMED), has filed a registration statement on Form S-1 with the SEC for a proposed initial public offering of newly issued common stock. The separation is expected to be completed through a series of capital markets transactions, with a preferred path of an IPO and subsequent split-off. MiniMed intends to apply to have its common stock listed on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol MMED. The number of shares to be offered and the price range for the offering have not yet been determined. The IPO is expected to commence after the completion of the SEC review process, subject to market and other conditions. Goldman Sachs & Co., BofA Securities, Citigroup and Morgan Stanley will act as the active bookrunners for the proposed offering. Barclays Capital, Deutsche Bank Securities, Mizuho Securities, Wells Fargo Securities, Evercore ISI and Piper Sandler & Co. will also act as joint bookrunning managers and BTIG, LLC and William Blair & Company will act as co-managers.

name: IBM
title: Production-ready gen AI: What Frontkom learned building a scalable platform with IBM for ...
description:
One such client is Reis Nordland, the regional public transport provider for Nordland County in Norway.
Reis Nordland was saddled with repetitive customer service requests and the requirement to provide travel data around the clock.
Frontkom’s conversational AI assistant connects to real-time transit feeds and structured internal data, such as timetables, traffic updates, FAQs and service policies.
To support rapid iteration while maintaining control and observability, Frontkom built a component-based architecture centered on IBM technologies and open-source tooling.
All conversational data, agent telemetry and configuration metadata persist in IBM Cloud Databases for PostgreSQL.
text:
With the initial euphoria surrounding generative AI settling into a more realistic search for ROI, many businesses face the challenge of moving beyond prototypes. An overwhelming majority—95%, according to a recent MIT study—struggle to move from pilot to production with gen AI.

To help its clients buck the trend of high adoption with little to no meaningful business transformation, Frontkom, a Norway-based digital innovation firm, built a scalable, modular AI platform that delivers conversational assistants, search interfaces and retrieval applications for a range of customers—each with different data, scale and governance requirements.

One such client is Reis Nordland, the regional public transport provider for Nordland County in Norway. The company operates bus and ferry services across a vast northern region, managing schedules, ticketing and route information for travelers.

Frontkom developed and delivered a gen AI travel assistant that enables riders to ask natural-language questions, such as “When is the next ferry from Bodø?” or “Is route 300 delayed?” and receive accurate, up-to-date answers from a conversational assistant in multiple languages. Just weeks after launch, the application has cut inquiries to Reis Nordland’s customer service representatives by more than half.

Reis Nordland was saddled with repetitive customer service requests and the requirement to provide travel data around the clock. Frontkom’s conversational AI assistant connects to real-time transit feeds and structured internal data, such as timetables, traffic updates, FAQs and service policies. The goal was to provide factual, context-grounded responses, while keeping operators in full control of the responses a model provides.

This deployment improved traveler experience for the transit service provider, but it also demonstrated a template architecture that Frontkom reuses across other domains, including education, sustainability and municipal services.

To support rapid iteration while maintaining control and observability, Frontkom built a component-based architecture centered on IBM technologies and open-source tooling.

At the front end, a lightweight embeddable chat widget—built with JavaScript and React—integrates directly into the Reis Nordland website and mobile applications. This widget is paired with a secure dashboard interface built on Supabase, allowing Reis Nordland operators to manage their AI agents, datasets and knowledge bases from a single, user-friendly console.

The orchestration layer is powered by Langflow, IBM’s low-code visual environment for building AI agent applications. Langflow manages the logic, prompt design and response shaping behind each AI agent. This enables Frontkom to update components, including LLMs, data connectors or workflows, independently without affecting production stability.

After some research, the Frontkom team settled on the Gemini 2.5 Flash model for Reis Nordland’s use case. Should new or different models (or tools) become more appropriate in the next six months, updating will be a simple task, thanks to Langflow’s drag-and-drop modularity.

Langflow runs on Frontkom PaaS, a Kubernetes-based infrastructure hosted on AWS. It uses Horizontal Pod Autoscaling (HPA) and Pod Disruption Budgets (PDB) to maintain reliability under variable traffic loads. A Fastly CDN sits in front of the system to ensure fast global delivery for both end users and administrative interfaces.

All conversational data, agent telemetry and configuration metadata persist in IBM Cloud Databases for PostgreSQL. This choice provides both scalability and governance, with version control that tracks every flow and dataset used in production

Reis Nordland’s assistant now handles thousands of daily interactions, providing travelers with fast, multilingual responses. Updating the app is a far simpler process; The team can roll out new features or datasets in hours rather than weeks.

Support tickets have dropped significantly: in the first week alone, the new system resolved over 1,300 support tickets, prompting Reis Norland to describe its AI assistant as a “very valuable employee.” And the results keep getting better.

Four weeks after launch, the number of inquiries to the customer center decreased by 37% compared to last year. After six weeks, that statistic improved to 55%. At the same time, customer center response times were cut nearly in half (to about one day), despite fewer resources for manual answering. This is a result of fewer inquiries, as the chatbot is taking on the burden of answering many questions.

More importantly, the same architecture is being reused for other Frontkom clients—demonstrating that production-grade gen AI is repeatable when the foundation is modular, observable and governed.

Learn more about Langflow

name: Medtronic
title: Medtronic's MiniMed files for US IPO - MarketScreener
description:
Dec 19 (Reuters) - Medtronic's MiniMed Group filed for a U.S. initial public offering on Friday, as the medical device maker moves ahead with the spin-off of its diabetes business.
Fuel distributor ARKO Petroleum and drug developer Aktis Oncology also publicly filed paperwork for a New York IPO on Friday.
In May, Medtronic said it planned to spin off its diabetes unit through an IPO, followed by a subsequent split-off.
MiniMed, which has tapped more than 10 underwriters for the offering, will list on the Nasdaq under the symbol "MMED".
MiniMed plans to use IPO proceeds to repay debt owed to Medtronic and for other purposes.
text:
Dec 19 (Reuters) - Medtronic's MiniMed Group filed for a U.S. initial public offering on Friday, as the medical device maker moves ahead with the spin-off of its diabetes business.

With capital markets set for a slowdown through the year-end holidays, corporate issuers are laying the groundwork for a potential roadshow launch in early 2026 when the IPO market kicks back into action.

Fuel distributor ARKO Petroleum and drug developer Aktis Oncology also publicly filed paperwork for a New York IPO on Friday.

U.S.-listed IPOs have raised $75.3 billion as of December 17, the biggest yearly haul since 2021, according to data from Dealogic.

"We expect the rebound to continue in 2026, in part because there's a lot of recent news of private companies planning 2026 IPOs," said Nicholas Einhorn, director of research at Renaissance Capital, a provider of IPO-focused research and ETFs.

Northridge, California-based MiniMed, whose offerings range from insulin delivery devices to glucose monitors, was founded in 1983 by Alfred Mann and bought by Medtronic in a nearly $3.3 billion deal in 2001.

The diabetes unit has grappled with regulatory concerns over quality management and cybersecurity issues related to its certain devices in the recent years, but has since returned to growth.

In May, Medtronic said it planned to spin off its diabetes unit through an IPO, followed by a subsequent split-off.

MiniMed reported a net loss of $21 million on net sales of $1.48 billion in the six months ended October 24, compared with net loss of $23 million on net sales of $1.30 billion a year earlier.

Goldman Sachs, BofA Securities, Citigroup and Morgan Stanley are the lead underwriters for the IPO. MiniMed, which has tapped more than 10 underwriters for the offering, will list on the Nasdaq under the symbol "MMED".

MiniMed plans to use IPO proceeds to repay debt owed to Medtronic and for other purposes.

(Reporting by Arasu Kannagi Basil in Bengaluru; Editing by Shinjini Ganguli and Shailesh Kuber)

By Arasu Kannagi Basil

name: Eli Lilly
title: Trump Announces Pricing Deals With Nine Drugmakers - The New York Times
description:
Mr. Trump has now reached deals with 14 of the 17 drugmakers to which he sent letters in July demanding that they lower prices.
Over the last few months, Mr. Trump has announced similar agreements with Pfizer, AstraZeneca, EMD Serono, Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk.
To help patients navigate that process, the Trump administration plans to create a site called TrumpRx.gov, which will direct patients to the manufacturers’ direct-buy websites.
Mr. Trump has repeatedly threatened to impose punishing tariffs on imported medicines but has not followed through.
The agreements also stop short of regulation that would force drugmakers to lower their prices, an approach Mr. Trump tried unsuccessfully in his first term.
text:
President Trump on Friday announced deals with nine pharmaceutical companies to reduce some drug prices, the latest step in his bid to try to align U.S. costs with the lower drug prices in European countries.

Mr. Trump has now reached deals with 14 of the 17 drugmakers to which he sent letters in July demanding that they lower prices. The nine companies participating in Friday’s announcement are Amgen, Boehringer Ingelheim, Bristol Myers Squibb, Roche’s Genentech unit, Gilead, GSK, Merck, Novartis and Sanofi.

Drugmakers have been eager to strike voluntary deals with the administration in hopes of avoiding punitive regulatory action that could cut deeply into their profits. Over the last few months, Mr. Trump has announced similar agreements with Pfizer, AstraZeneca, EMD Serono, Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk.

The three major drugmakers that have yet to announce deals with the administration are AbbVie, Johnson & Johnson and Regeneron. Alexandra Bowie, a spokeswoman for Regeneron, said her company was still in talks with the administration.

Under the arrangements, the manufacturers will offer some of their drugs through websites where Americans can bypass insurance and use their own money to buy the products.

To help patients navigate that process, the Trump administration plans to create a site called TrumpRx.gov, which will direct patients to the manufacturers’ direct-buy websites. Officials put up a promotional version of the TrumpRx website this fall and said they plan for it to be operational in January.

The drugmakers also agreed to sell most of their products to state Medicaid programs, which provide health insurance for low-income Americans, at the prices they offer to other wealthy countries.

Medicaid is already legally required to get the lowest drug prices in the United States, which are often comparable to those in European countries. But administration officials said the deals would bring significant savings for some drugs.

The drugmakers also said they would introduce new medicines in the United States at prices comparable to what they ask other wealthy countries to pay.

In exchange, the companies secured three-year exemptions from any tariffs that Mr. Trump might impose on imported pharmaceuticals, administration officials said. Mr. Trump has repeatedly threatened to impose punishing tariffs on imported medicines but has not followed through.

In the United States, prices for brand-name drugs are three times as high, on average, as those in peer nations. Mr. Trump has long complained that the United States is unfairly subsidizing lower prices in European countries, a view echoed by many pharmaceutical executives.

The deals announced on Friday do not address the high costs of most drugs already on the market covered under private insurance or other government health insurance programs like Medicare. Those costs are borne by U.S. employers and consumers who pay in the form of taxes, health insurance premiums and out-of-pocket expenses.

The agreements also stop short of regulation that would force drugmakers to lower their prices, an approach Mr. Trump tried unsuccessfully in his first term.

name: S&P Global
title: CFOs On the Move: Week ending Dec. 19 | CFO.com
description:
Matthew Dunnigan | 7 Brew Drive-thru beverage brand 7 Brew hired Matthew Dunnigan as finance chief.
Before that, he was a vice president of the credit investment manager Crescent Capital.
Before that, he was the finance chief of DreamBox Learning, a K-12 education technology company.
Christy Schwartz | Opendoor Christy Schwartz was named finance chief of Opendoor, effective Jan. 1.
Before that, she was the company’s vice president and corporate controller.
text:
This audio is auto-generated. Please let us know if you have feedback.

Matt Calderone | S&P Global Mobility

S&P Global named Matt Calderone as CFO of its mobility business ahead of its planned spinoff. Calderone will join the company on March 1 from Booz Allen, where he has been CFO since 2022. He has held several leadership roles over his 22-year career at Booz Allen, including as chief strategy officer and EVP of FP&A, strategic finance and corporate development. During Calderone’s tenure at Booz Allen, he guided more than $1.5 billion in M&A transactions, designed and executed its 2020 growth strategy and led its restructuring in 2013

Maria Khoury | Marathon Petroleum

Maria Khoury will join Marathon Petroleum as its new finance chief on Jan. 19. Since 2021, Khoury has been vice president and Group CFO Biotechnology for life sciences and diagnostics firm Danaher, where she also has finance responsibility for Cytiva (formerly GE Healthcare Biopharma) and Pall Life Sciences. Khoury was previously the vice president of finance and IT for GE Healthcare Life Sciences, and she had earlier held leadership roles for GE Oil & Gas, including serving as CFO of GE’s Drilling and Surface division. Khoury succeeds John Quaid, who will stay with the company for a transition period.

David Evans | Cardlytics

Cardlytics former CFO David Evans will return to the role on Jan. 12. Evans previously worked at the digital advertising company from 2014 to 2020, where he played a key role in its IPO in 2018. He held the CFO role for over five years before transitioning to chief administrative officer for seven months and then left the company. Most recently, he has been an adviser and board member of several companies in the software and technology sectors, including his current role as board chair at Neighborly Software. Evans replaces Alexis DeSieno, who is stepping down as CFO. DeSieno will work in a non-officer advisory capacity until March 6, 2026.

Matthew Dunnigan | 7 Brew

Drive-thru beverage brand 7 Brew hired Matthew Dunnigan as finance chief. Dunnigan most recently spent six years as CFO of Restaurant Brands International, the parent company of fast food chains Tim Hortons, Burger King, Popeyes and Firehouse Subs. He joined Restaurant Brands International in 2014 as treasurer. Before that, he was a vice president of the credit investment manager Crescent Capital.

Keep up with the story. Subscribe to the CFO.com free daily newsletter

Lance Ludman | SurveyMonkey

SurveyMonkey appointed Lance Ludman as the survey platform’s new chief financial officer. Ludman was most recently CFO of corporate purpose software provider Benevity. Before that, he was the finance chief of DreamBox Learning, a K-12 education technology company. Ludman spent over eight years at software provider Blackbaud, including as CFO for International. His early career included corporate development at Lockheed Martin.

Christy Schwartz | Opendoor

Christy Schwartz was named finance chief of Opendoor, effective Jan. 1. ​​Schwartz has been interim CFO of the online real estate platform since September, when she took over for Selim Freiha, who left the company. This wasn’t her first time as interim CFO; she was previously interim CFO from December 2022 to November 2024 and was the company’s chief accounting officer from March 2021 to May 2025. Before that, she was the company’s vice president and corporate controller.

Amy Butte | Navan

name: BNY Mellon
title: Lawsuits claim major banks enabled Jeffrey Epstein's sex trafficking finances
description:
The complaint claims the bank failed to file required Suspicious Activity Reports, or SARs, despite signs that Epstein’s financial behavior warranted closer scrutiny.
"Jeffrey Epstein apparently had so many excessive high cash withdrawals that it was causing some suspicion with the banks," Schneider said.
A separate class-action lawsuit against BNY Mellon makes similar allegations, asserting the bank had a "plethora of information" about Epstein's operation.
"The bank could face severe penalties from the federal government for not doing proper reporting of suspicious activity," Schneider told Scripps News.
The House Judiciary Committee has contacted JPMorgan Chase, Deutsche Bank, Bank of America and BNY Mellon, demanding financial records related to Epstein’s accounts and transactions.
text:
Two class-action lawsuits against Bank of America and BNY Mellon could shed new light on how convicted sex trafficker Jeffrey Epstein allegedly financed his abuse network, and the role major financial institutions may have played in enabling it.

The lawsuits, filed by an anonymous Jane Doe plaintiff, accuse the banks of ignoring red flags, failing to report suspicious transactions and, in doing so, providing Epstein with the financial infrastructure needed to sustain his operation.

However, at a motions hearing Monday, a federal judge expressed skepticism, suggesting he may dismiss them before they go to trial unless the lawyers revise their cases with more specific details about their allegations.

RELATED STORY | Lawmakers threaten legal action over delayed Epstein files release

The lawsuit against Bank of America alleges the company "knowingly provided the financial support and the veneer of institutional legitimacy" that allowed Epstein to operate under the "guise" of legitimate business activity.

The complaint claims the bank failed to file required Suspicious Activity Reports, or SARs, despite signs that Epstein’s financial behavior warranted closer scrutiny. The lawsuit describes that failure as "wrongful and purposeful."

Trial attorney Stacy Schneider, who is not involved in the case, told Scripps News in an interview that excessive cash withdrawals are a well-known trigger for mandatory reporting under federal banking regulations.

"Jeffrey Epstein apparently had so many excessive high cash withdrawals that it was causing some suspicion with the banks," Schneider said. "And what happens when someone is doing excessive cash withdrawals is the bank is required to file an SAR, which is a suspicious activity report."

A separate class-action lawsuit against BNY Mellon makes similar allegations, asserting the bank had a "plethora of information" about Epstein's operation.

EPSTEIN TIMELINE | From arrest and death to push for public release of DOJ files

The filing claims Epstein's crimes were enabled not only by his personal wealth and influence, but through "access to funding and financial support from both individuals and institutions, including B-N-Y."

"The bank could face severe penalties from the federal government for not doing proper reporting of suspicious activity," Schneider told Scripps News. "But proving what was suspicious and what isn't suspicious is done by a case-by-case basis."

Both Bank of America and BNY Mellon have asked a federal judge to dismiss the lawsuits, calling the claims “threadbare and meritless.”

The cases come amid mounting scrutiny of Wall Street’s past relationships with Epstein, who died by suicide in jail in 2019 while awaiting trial on federal sex trafficking charges.

The recent litigation follows major settlements by other financial institutions accused of overlooking Epstein’s conduct.

JPMorgan Chase agreed last year to pay $290 million to sexual abuse survivors who alleged the bank ignored warnings about Epstein’s behavior, though the bank did not admit wrongdoing as part of the settlement.

Deutsche Bank also reached a $75 million settlement, acknowledging it made a "critical mistake" in taking Epstein on as a client.

The House Judiciary Committee has contacted JPMorgan Chase, Deutsche Bank, Bank of America and BNY Mellon, demanding financial records related to Epstein’s accounts and transactions. Lawmakers allege the banks failed to take action for years, even as warning signs mounted.

A source familiar with the investigation confirmed to Scripps News that the Committee did receive responses from each bank, though they were largely non-responsive to the Committee’s questions. When pressed about whether they would provide documents, the banks either refused to answer or declined to do so absent a subpoena.

Committee Ranking Member Rep. Jamie Raskin, D-MD, says obtaining the records is critical to understanding the full scope of what happened and whether accountability has been avoided.

name: Nvidia
title: Boosting Nvidia's H200 Semiconductor Exports Won't Make US Safer - Bloomberg
description:
In deciding where to draw the line on sales of advanced semiconductors to China, the White House should prioritize the security of all Americans over the interests of individual companies.
Its latest moves risk getting that balance wrong.
Earlier this month, the president granted Nvidia Corp. permission to ship its H200 artificial intelligence chips to China, while loosening restrictions on rivals Intel Corp. and Advanced Micro Devices Inc. as well.
Although not Nvidia’s most cutting-edge offering, the H200 is at least a generation ahead of Chinese-made alternatives.
Moreover, the Commerce Department has estimated that Huawei will only produce 200,000 Ascend chips this year, compared to the 14 million AI chips deployed by US companies.
text:
In deciding where to draw the line on sales of advanced semiconductors to China, the White House should prioritize the security of all Americans over the interests of individual companies. Its latest moves risk getting that balance wrong.

Earlier this month, the president granted Nvidia Corp. permission to ship its H200 artificial intelligence chips to China, while loosening restrictions on rivals Intel Corp. and Advanced Micro Devices Inc. as well. Although not Nvidia’s most cutting-edge offering, the H200 is at least a generation ahead of Chinese-made alternatives. According to the Institute for Progress, it provides 32% more processing power (useful for training AI models) and 50% more memory bandwidth (which helps those models run) than the Ascend 910C, the best chip from Huawei Technologies Co. Ltd.; it’s also cheaper to use and more reliable. Moreover, the Commerce Department has estimated that Huawei will only produce 200,000 Ascend chips this year, compared to the 14 million AI chips deployed by US companies.

name: OpenAI
title: Sam Altman says he has '0%' excitement about being CEO of a public company
description:
Sam Altman, the CEO of OpenAI, has mixed feelings about taking his company public.
"Am I excited for OpenAI to be a public company?
Leadership seems to be one of the sticking points for Altman: "Am I excited to be a public company CEO?
In October, the company reached a $500 billion valuation after a secondary share sale, briefly overtaking Elon Musk's SpaceX to become the most valuable private company in the world, a crown that SpaceX regained in recent days.
"We will be very late to go public," Altman added.
text:
Sam Altman, the CEO of OpenAI, has mixed feelings about taking his company public.

"Am I excited for OpenAI to be a public company? In some ways, I am, and in some ways I think it'd be really annoying," Altman said on an episode of the "Big Technology Podcast" published Thursday.

Leadership seems to be one of the sticking points for Altman: "Am I excited to be a public company CEO? 0%."

"It's wonderful to be a private company," Altman said, but he added that OpenAI needs lots of capital and is going to "cross all of the shareholder limits and stuff at some point."

"I do think it's cool that public markets get to participate in value creation," Altman said.

Altman cofounded OpenAI alongside eleven others in 2015, and the company's value has soared since the launch of its AI-powered chatbot, ChatGPT, in 2022.

ChatGPT has 800 million weekly users, and the company has inked $1 trillion worth of deals with tech giants like Oracle, Nvidia, and AMD.

In October, the company reached a $500 billion valuation after a secondary share sale, briefly overtaking Elon Musk's SpaceX to become the most valuable private company in the world, a crown that SpaceX regained in recent days.

The Information reported on Wednesday that OpenAI is seeking to raise billions more at a $750 billion valuation.

There are signs the company is preparing for a potential IPO. In October, Reuters reported that OpenAI is considering filing with securities regulators as soon as the second half of 2026.

But asked during the podcast if OpenAI would IPO next year, Altman responded, "I don't know."

"We will be very late to go public," Altman added.

name: Nvidia
title: US launches review of advanced Nvidia AI chip sales to China, sources say - CNA
description:
But questions have remained about ⁠how ‍quickly the US might approve such sales and whether Beijing would allow Chinese firms to purchase the Nvidia chips.
One of ‍the sources, an administration official, emphasised the review would be thorough and "not some perfunctory box we are checking".
BIDEN HAD BANNED ADVANCED AI CHIP SALES TO CHINA The Biden administration had imposed a raft of restrictions on advanced AI chip sales to China and countries it ‌feared could become conduits for smuggling into the rival nation, citing national security fears.
Led by White House AI czar David Sacks, several members of the Trump administration now argue that shipping advanced AI chips to China discourages Chinese competitors like Huawei from redoubling efforts to catch up with Nvidia's and AMD's most-advanced chip designs.
While the H200 chips are slower than Nvidia's Blackwell chips at many AI tasks, they remain in wide use in the industry and have never been allowed for sale in China.
text:
WASHINGTON: United States President Donald Trump's administration has launched a review that could result in ⁠the first shipments to China of Nvidia's second-most powerful artificial intelligence (AI) chips, five sources said, making good on his pledge to allow the controversial sales.

Trump this month said he would allow sales of Nvidia's H200 chips to China, with the US government collecting a 25 per cent fee, and that the sales would help keep US firms ahead of Chinese chipmakers by cutting demand for Chinese chips.

Advertisement

The move drew fire from China hawks across the US political spectrum over concerns the chips would supercharge Beijing's military and erode the US ‍advantage in artificial intelligence. But questions have remained about ⁠how ‍quickly the US might approve such sales and whether Beijing would allow Chinese firms to purchase the Nvidia chips.

The US Commerce Department, which oversees export policy, has sent license applications for the chip sales to the State, Energy and Defense Departments ⁠for review, the sources said on condition of anonymity because the process is not public.

Those agencies have 30 days to weigh in, according to export regulations.

One of ‍the sources, an administration official, emphasised the review would be thorough and "not some perfunctory box we are checking".

But under the regulations, the final decision rests with Trump.

Advertisement

The start of the inter-agency licensing review has not been reported previously. The Commerce Department and Nvidia did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

A White House spokesperson did not comment on the review, but said "the Trump administration is committed to ensuring the dominance of the American tech stack – without compromising on national security".

BIDEN HAD BANNED ADVANCED AI CHIP SALES TO CHINA

The Biden administration had imposed a raft of restrictions on advanced AI chip sales to China and countries it ‌feared could become conduits for smuggling into the rival nation, citing national security fears.

Trump's move represents a departure from that policy and a dramatic reversal from his first term, when he drew international attention by cracking down on Chinese ‍access ‌to US technology. Back then, he cited claims that Beijing steals American intellectual property and harnesses commercially obtained technology to bolster its military, which Beijing denies.

Exporting large numbers of the chips to China would be "a significant strategic mistake", said Chris McGuire, a former White House National Security Council official under President Joe Biden and senior fellow with the Council on Foreign Relations.

Advertisement

McGuire described the chips as "the one thing holding China back in AI".

"I cannot possibly fathom how the departments of Commerce, State, Energy, and Defense could certify that exporting these chips to China is in ‌the US national security interest,” he said.

Led by White House AI czar David Sacks, several members of the Trump administration now argue that shipping advanced AI chips to China discourages Chinese competitors like Huawei from redoubling efforts to catch up with Nvidia's and AMD's most-advanced chip designs.

Reuters reported last week that Nvidia was considering an increase in production of the H200, the immediate predecessor to its current flagship Blackwell chips, after initial orders from China outstripped the current capacity.

While the H200 chips are slower than Nvidia's Blackwell chips at many AI tasks, they remain in wide use in the industry and have never been allowed for sale in China.

Advertisement

Trump had previously opened the door to sales of a less-advanced version of Nvidia's Blackwell chips, its cutting-edge offering, but backed away from the ‌move and approved sales of the H200 instead.

name: Nvidia
title: Nvidia and Google Back $6.6B AI Startup Lovable - TechRepublic
description:
Stockholm-based AI startup Lovable has some admirers, with two of them being tech heavyweights Nvidia and Google.
The round was led by CapitalG (Alphabet’s venture arm) and Menlo Ventures, with participation from Nvidia’s NVentures, creating an alliance of AI powerhouses.
With fresh funding exceeding $500 million raised in 2025 alone, Lovable is probably loving life.
Investment frenzy The funding announcement signals a massive shift in how tech giants view AI development tools.
While Nvidia wants to secure GPU demand from the next generation of AI applications, Alphabet’s CapitalG aims to push AI tools that could challenge traditional software monopolies.
text:
Stockholm-based AI startup Lovable has some admirers, with two of them being tech heavyweights Nvidia and Google.

The vibe coding noob has closed a $330 million Series B funding round, catapulting the company to a healthy $6.6 billion valuation. This figure represents more than triple the company’s worth from five months ago, when it was valued at $1.8 billion following its July funding round. The round was led by CapitalG (Alphabet’s venture arm) and Menlo Ventures, with participation from Nvidia’s NVentures, creating an alliance of AI powerhouses.

Back in 2023, this Swedish startup was founded by Anton Osika and Fabian Hedin, and has since become one of the fastest-growing companies in tech history. Lovable reached $200 million in annual recurring revenue last month, achieving this milestone in under a year after hitting its first $1 million in ARR. With fresh funding exceeding $500 million raised in 2025 alone, Lovable is probably loving life.

I’m worth billions in prizes

Behind Lovable’s meteoric rise lies vibe coding—an approach that transforms simple text descriptions into fully functional applications. Users can generate complete websites or applications by typing casual prompts into a chatbot interface, with no coding knowledge required.

Numbers from the announcement reveal Lovable’s user base creates over 100,000 new applications daily, with more than 25 million projects built on the platform in its first year. Major enterprise customers including Klarna, Uber, and Zendesk are already using the platform, with some teams reducing development time from six weeks to just three hours.

Investment frenzy

The funding announcement signals a massive shift in how tech giants view AI development tools. Nvidia’s investment strategy focuses on backing startups it considers game changers and market makers to expand the AI ecosystem. The company has already participated in 50 venture capital deals this year, surpassing its entire 2024 activity.

Market data from earlier this quarter shows vibe coding exploding across the board. Combined valuations of leading startups in this space grew 350% year-over-year, jumping from roughly $7-8 billion in mid-2024 to over $36 billion in 2025. Competitor Cursor raised $2.3 billion at a $29.3 billion valuation last month, while Replit hit a $3 billion valuation in September.

Strategic positioning reveals competing interests converging around this Swedish startup. While Nvidia wants to secure GPU demand from the next generation of AI applications, Alphabet’s CapitalG aims to push AI tools that could challenge traditional software monopolies. When these competing tech giants agree on backing the same company, something transformative is clearly happening.

Sweet software development

The announcement arguably represents more than just another AI success story—it validates a fundamental shift in how software gets built. The company’s mission to become “the last piece of software” companies ever need to buy reflects growing demand for platforms that eliminate traditional development bottlenecks.

The platform addresses the global shortage of skilled programmers by transforming millions of non-technical users into developers. When you examine the implications, Lovable has transformed a latent market of tens of millions of people into developers.

Enterprise adoption signals are undeniable. Lovable’s demand from Fortune 500 companies signals a fundamental shift in how software gets built. The company plans to use its new funding to enhance collaboration and governance capabilities, add more third-party software integrations, and application hosting features.

Reduced implementation timeline: With AI-assisted automation, Qualified Digital slashes the technical implementation and configuration timeline, allowing businesses to activate the Adobe Experience Platform Web SDK in a matter of days instead of multiple weeks.
About Qualified Digital Qualified Digital (QD) is a leading full-service digital consultancy agency, specializing in customer experience and digital transformation.
Qualified Digital aims to deliver true customer journey orchestration, automation, and personalization, enabling you and your organization to drive meaningful experiences together.
text:
RENO, Nev., December 18, 2025--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Qualified Digital (QD), a leading full-service digital business and experience agency, announced the launch of its AI-assisted migration accelerator, designed to dramatically speed up the transition to the Adobe Experience Platform Web SDK. This innovative solution transforms what has traditionally been a manual, resource-intensive process into a lightning-fast, streamlined deployment.

The new accelerator is specifically engineered to address the common bottlenecks associated with migrating from legacy codebases like appmeasurement.js (Adobe Analytics) and at.js (Adobe Target) to the Adobe Experience Platform Web SDK, offering unparalleled speed and efficiency for enterprises looking to modernize and upgrade their data collection methodology to the latest standard.

Key Benefits

Unmatched time-to-value with Customer Journey Analytics:

By accelerating the foundational technical setup, the solution drastically reduces the overall value realization timeline for Customer Journey Analytics (CJA), enabling clients to mostly focus on insight generation, not technical setup.

Reduced implementation timeline: With AI-assisted automation, Qualified Digital slashes the technical implementation and configuration timeline, allowing businesses to activate the Adobe Experience Platform Web SDK in a matter of days instead of multiple weeks.

Enterprise ready: The accelerator enables a fast and scalable migration by automating complex and repetitive tasks. This significantly reduces the time needed to move from older Adobe data collection methods to the unified AEP Web SDK, regardless of whether your Adobe Tags property contains tens or hundreds of tags.

Human in the loop

While the AI-assisted automation takes care of the major technical migration tasks, the human, in this case the analytics implementation engineer, stays in full control of the validation and publishing process.

"By minimizing the manual implementation burden, our AI-assisted accelerator helps clients realize value with Customer Journey Analytics and the rest of the Adobe Experience Platform solutions faster," said Kevin Haag, SVP of Data Strategy at Qualified Digital.

Qualified Digital's AI-assisted migration accelerator is available immediately to new and existing Adobe Experience Cloud customers looking to modernize their data collection framework and rapidly unlock the full potential of the Adobe Experience Platform and its application services Real-Time CDP, Customer Journey Analytics, Journey Optimizer & Mixed Modeler.

About Qualified Digital

Qualified Digital (QD) is a leading full-service digital consultancy agency, specializing in customer experience and digital transformation. Founded in 2017 by CEO Jaqi Saleem, QD leverages its expertise in B2B and B2C business and marketing, prioritizing strategy in customer experience, data, content, and technology. Qualified Digital aims to deliver true customer journey orchestration, automation, and personalization, enabling you and your organization to drive meaningful experiences together.

With a strategic focus on Fortune 500+ companies, and specializations across healthcare and the complexities of B2B marketing life cycles, QD is dedicated to cultivating long-term relationships that drive unmatched customer experience and digital return on investment by keeping a close pulse on a brand’s needs and opportunities. Learn more at www.qualifiedigital.com.

title: Electric vehicle market in Indonesia - International Council on Clean Transportation
description:
A zero-emission vehicle is any vehicle with a propulsion system producing zero combustion emissions, such as a dedicated battery electric, fuel-cell electric, or other motor that is not driven by combustion.
A passenger car is a vehicle intended to transport passengers that has a maximum gross vehicle weight below 3.5 tons.
A light commercial vehicle is a commercial vehicle intended for the transport of freight with a gross vehicle weight below 3.5 tons.
A heavy-duty vehicle is a commercial vehicle intended for the transport of passengers or freight with a gross vehicle weight above 3.5 tons.
Most data on passenger cars, light commercial vehicles, and heavy-duty vehicles were supplied by S&P Global.
text:
A zero-emission vehicle is any vehicle with a propulsion system producing zero combustion emissions, such as a dedicated battery electric, fuel-cell electric, or other motor that is not driven by combustion.

A passenger car is a vehicle intended to transport passengers that has a maximum gross vehicle weight below 3.5 tons. The Indonesian classification used for this vehicle segment is M1.

A light commercial vehicle is a commercial vehicle intended for the transport of freight with a gross vehicle weight below 3.5 tons. The Indonesian classification used for this vehicle segment is N1.

A heavy-duty vehicle is a commercial vehicle intended for the transport of passengers or freight with a gross vehicle weight above 3.5 tons. The Indonesian classification of this vehicle segment is N2, N3, M2, and M3.

Most data on passenger cars, light commercial vehicles, and heavy-duty vehicles were supplied by S&P Global. (Copyright © S&P Global 2025. All rights reserved.) Data on batteries for passenger cars and sales numbers for VinFast and Tesla were sourced from EV Volumes. Data on motorcycles and mopeds, including battery information, were supplied by Motorcycle Data. (Copyright Motorcycle Data 2025.)

About original equipment manufacturers

Original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) are companies that design, manufacture, and sell complete vehicles under their own brand names. Because they bring complete vehicles to market, unlike component suppliers and aftermarket manufacturers, OEMs bear full regulatory responsibility for their products, meaning they must ensure compliance with safety standards, emission regulations, and other governmental requirements across their operating markets. The designation “original” reflects the fact that OEMs are primary brand owners and market-facing entities.
